results.title: Birth: a film about feelings and experiences
results.creator_credit: Julian Aston, Julian Aston Productions and National Childbirth Trust
results.brief_description: A film in which women discuss their emotional response to childbirth as well as the physical experience. The importance of prenatal exercises is discussed and an actual birth is shown.

results.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Merry-go-round”.
Birth describes the steps in child delivery and the special characteristics of the new born. Simple drawings and other references to the animal world explain the general birth process, while animated illustrations showing the movement of the human embryo provide details on labour and anatomy. One sequence allows the viewer to witness the actual moment of a baby’s birth and the steps that follow. Commentary by Richard Carpenter, Melissa Docker. Animation by Barry Merritt. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Birth, sex and death
results.creator_credit: Tim Haines, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cracking the code”.
The cycle of human life is controlled by genes. Could genes also programme our time of death, or do they just prefer the offspring who carry on?

results.title: Birth without knives
results.brief_description:
Please note: This film contains footage of a home birth, including nudity.

Created by ‘Asphyxia’, this film talks about the concerns regarding pregnancy, avoiding a caesarean birth and having a home birth.

Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’.

results.title: Birth with Dr. R.D. Laing
results.creator_credit: Helen Brew, Media Insights and Sam Pillsbury
results.brief_description: Questions and challenges many aspects of modern childbirth practices. Poses such questions as: why do mothers have little say in the services that exist entirely for them? Why does this occasion for the celebration of life turn so often into an emotional and biological disaster? R. D. Laing talks about his ideas on childbirth. A group of mothers discuss their experiences in hospitals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Brew, Media Insights and Sam Pillsbury

results.title: Birth rediscovered
results.brief_description: A documentary about childbirth at home. This program traces the experience, during the final 24 hours up to the birth of the child of a couple who have decided to have their baby at home.

results.title: Birth reborn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
Looks at the work in France of Dr Michael Odent who firmly opposes standard medical thinking on childbirth practices. He advocates that women should be able to give birth in the position in which they feel most comfortable rather than being forced into the “stranded beetle” (legs in stirrups) position commonly used in hospitals. Shows a series of births in which Dr Odent helps women to give birth naturally and with a minimum amount of pain. Also depicts the work of Dr Odent in his pre-birth classes where he encourages women to give birth in different positions: standing or squatting. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Birth of the soil
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”.
This film shows how nature produces life-giving topsoil from the basic raw materials of rock, air, and sunlight, by the processes of plant growth and decay and photosynthesis.

results.title: Birth of the red kangaroo
results.brief_description: Shows mating, the female kangaroo’s preparation for the birth of her young and birth itself. Explains the significance of the oestrous cycle and gestation period, egg fertilization, and the development of the embryo in the uterus. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Birth of the bomb [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty and Peter Batty Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visions of War”.
This is the background story of the making of the first atomic bomb. The period covered is from 1938 to the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. German efforts to create an atomic bomb are described. The intensive research into the development of the bomb in the United States is dealt with extensively. Includes archival film and interviews with some of those involved. (Black and white version)
